texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: /2015/06/08/pulseaudio-popping-with-multiple-sounds-in-fedora-22/
texts.text: /2015/06/08/pulseaudio-popping-with-multiple-sounds-in-fedora-22/

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: fedora
texts.text: fedora

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: pulseaudio
texts.text: pulseaudio

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: My transition from Fedora 21 to 22 on the ThinkPad X1 Carbon was fairly uneventful even with over 2,400 packages involved in the upgrade. The only problem I dealt with on reboot was that my icons on the GNOME 3 desktop were way too large. That's a pretty easy problem to fix.
texts.text: My transition from Fedora 21 to 22 on the ThinkPad X1 Carbon was fairly uneventful even with over 2,400 packages involved in the upgrade. The only problem I dealt with on reboot was that my icons on the GNOME 3 desktop were way too large. That's a pretty easy problem to fix.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: However, something else cropped up after a while. I started listening to music in Chrome and a Pidgin notification sound came through. There was a quiet pop before the Pidgin sound and a loud pop on the end. Thunderbird's notifications sounded the same. The pops at the end of the sound were sometimes  very  loud and hurt my ears.
texts.text: However, something else cropped up after a while. I started listening to music in Chrome and a Pidgin notification sound came through. There was a quiet pop before the Pidgin sound and a loud pop on the end. Thunderbird's notifications sounded the same. The pops at the end of the sound were sometimes  very  loud and hurt my ears.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I started running PulseAudio in debug mode within a terminal:
texts.text: I started running PulseAudio in debug mode within a terminal:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
pulseaudio -k
pulseaudio --start
texts.text:
pulseaudio -k
pulseaudio --start

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: There were some messages about buffer underruns and latency issues but they were all very minimal. I loaded up  pavucontrol  and couldn't find anything unusual when multiple sounds played. I gave  pavumeter  a try and found something very interesting.
texts.text: There were some messages about buffer underruns and latency issues but they were all very minimal. I loaded up  pavucontrol  and couldn't find anything unusual when multiple sounds played. I gave  pavumeter  a try and found something very interesting.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: When Chrome was playing audio, the meters in pavumeter were at 80-90%. That seems to make sense because I keep Chrome as one of the loudest applications on my laptop. My logic there is that I don't want to get blasted by a notification tone that is drastically louder than my music.
texts.text: When Chrome was playing audio, the meters in pavumeter were at 80-90%. That seems to make sense because I keep Chrome as one of the loudest applications on my laptop. My logic there is that I don't want to get blasted by a notification tone that is drastically louder than my music.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: However, if I received a Pidgin or Thunderbird notification while Chrome was playing music, the pavumeter showed the volume levels dropping to 30% or less. As soon as the sound was over, the meters snapped back to 80-90% and there was a big popping sound. I lowered Chrome's volume so that it showed up at the 30% level in pavumeter and forced a new Pidgin notification sound - the pops were still there.
texts.text: However, if I received a Pidgin or Thunderbird notification while Chrome was playing music, the pavumeter showed the volume levels dropping to 30% or less. As soon as the sound was over, the meters snapped back to 80-90% and there was a big popping sound. I lowered Chrome's volume so that it showed up at the 30% level in pavumeter and forced a new Pidgin notification sound - the pops were still there.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I started searching in Google and stumbled upon  ArchLinux's PulseAudio documentation . (Their documentation is really awesome.) There's a mention of the  flat-volumes  PulseAudio configuration option. If it's set to  no , you get the older ALSA functionality where volumes can be set independently per application. The default is  yes  and that default comes with a warning in the documentation:
texts.text: I started searching in Google and stumbled upon  ArchLinux's PulseAudio documentation . (Their documentation is really awesome.) There's a mention of the  flat-volumes  PulseAudio configuration option. If it's set to  no , you get the older ALSA functionality where volumes can be set independently per application. The default is  yes  and that default comes with a warning in the documentation:

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Warning: The default behavior can sometimes be confusing and some applications, unaware of this feature, can set their volume to 100% at startup, potentially blowing your speakers or your ears. To restore the classic (ALSA) behavior set this to no.
texts.text: Warning: The default behavior can sometimes be confusing and some applications, unaware of this feature, can set their volume to 100% at startup, potentially blowing your speakers or your ears. To restore the classic (ALSA) behavior set this to no.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: As a test, I switched  flat-volumes  to  no  in
texts.text: As a test, I switched  flat-volumes  to  no  in

texts.label: code
texts.orig: /etc/pulse/daemon.conf
texts.text: /etc/pulse/daemon.conf

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: . I restarted PulseAudio with the new setting:
texts.text: . I restarted PulseAudio with the new setting:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
pulseaudio -k
pulseaudio --start
texts.text:
pulseaudio -k
pulseaudio --start

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I started music in Chrome and sent myself an IM in Pidgin. No pops! An email came through and Thunderbird and a notification sound played. No pops there, either!
texts.text: I started music in Chrome and sent myself an IM in Pidgin. No pops! An email came through and Thunderbird and a notification sound played. No pops there, either!

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: GNOME 3 was a bit unhappy at my PulseAudio tinkering and the volume control disappeared from the menu at the top right. I logged out of my GNOME session and logged back in to find the volume control working again.
texts.text: GNOME 3 was a bit unhappy at my PulseAudio tinkering and the volume control disappeared from the menu at the top right. I logged out of my GNOME session and logged back in to find the volume control working again.
